questions.text: All are the phases of parturition, EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Phases of Parturition

Parturition, the bringing forth of young, encompasses all physiological processes involved in birthing

Phase 1 = Prelude to parturition

Phase 2 (Activation) = Preparation for labor

Phase 3 (Stimulation) =Processes of labor

Phase 4 (Involution) =Parturient recovery

The clinical stages of labor, which are the first, second, and third stages together make up phase 3 of parturition.

Please note: The phases of parturition should not be confused with the clinical stages of labor

questions.text: The first permanent tooth to erupt is:
questions.solution:
• The first permanent molars usually erupt between ages 6 and 7 years.
  • For that reason, they often are called the six-year molars.
  • They are among the “extra" permanent teeth, in that they don't replace an existing primary tooth.
  • These important teeth sometimes are mistaken for primary teeth.
  • The six-year molars also help determine the shape of the lower face and affect the position and health of other permanent teeth.
  • The first deciduous teeth to fall are central incisors.

questions.text: What is the causative organism of the following image:
questions.solution:
These verrucous perianal lesions suggest the diagnosis of condyloma acuminata. Condyloma acuminata, or genital warts

  • Condyloma acuminata is caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV). High-risk HPV strains include HPV 16 and 18, which cause about 70% of cervical cancers. Other high-risk human papillomaviruses include 31, 33, 45, 52, 58, and a few others. Low- risk HPV strains, such as HPV 6 and 11, cause about 90% of genital warts, which rarely develop into cancer..
  • It infects epidermal cells and can cause warty growths. When the virus affects skin cells on the hands, the result is the common warts that are often seen in children. When the virus affects cells on the perineum, the result is condyloma acuminata.
  • Diagnosis is made on the basis of the classic, verrucous (cauliflower-like) appearance of the lesions.
  • Treatment is with local destruction.
  • This local destruction can be achieved in a variety of ways including with cryotherapy (i.e. freezing of the skin), laser therapy, trichloroacetic acid (i.e. chemical destruction of the skin), or imiquimod. However, while the lesions themselves are often successfully treated with these locally destructive agents, the virus is not usually completely eradicated and recurrences of the lesions may occur.. Cone biopsy is performed on the cervix when a patient has high-grade dysplasia or cancer. While there is an association between human papillomavirus infection and cervical dysplasia, cone biopsy would not be indicated for a patient on the basis of the presence of condyloma. Vulvectomy is performed on patients for vulvar dysplasia or cancer. It is not indicated for patients with condyloma

questions.text: A 60 year old male came in due to dysuria and pain in the hypogastric region. Upon DRE, a palpable mass was felt in the 9 o clock position with suspected malignancy. Mla - Distant metastasis in non-regional LN

M1b - Distant metastasis to bone M1c - Distant metastasis to other sites

ACHALASIA CARDIA

Equal distribution (M = F)

  • It has 2 types of neurons

    • Achalasia

    • ACTH Resistant Adrenal Insufficiency

Investigation

Findings of Manometry

LES Related

Esophageal body Related Absence of LES relaxation

Increased Esophageal Pressure

questions.text: Insulinoma is a pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor which can contribute to obstructive jaundice and other features that can mimic pancreatic adenocarcinoma. All of the following are included in Whipple’s triad except?

choices.text: Immediate relief of symptoms with IV glucose

questions.solution:
INSULINOMA

  • It is Pancreatic Neuroendocrine Tumor > Overall leading causes of functioning Pancreatic Neuroendocrine Tumor.
  • Overall leading cause of non-functioning Pancreatic Neuroendocrine Tumor = PP-OMA (pancreatic polypeptide) Doesn't cause any symptoms from perspective of hormones but will produce mass effect, which can contribute to obstructive jaundice & other features that can mimic pancreatic adenocarcinoma. Insulin high
  • If Sugar lever fall < 54 mg%- patient will have symptoms of Hypoglycemia Normally, When Blood sugar < 70 mg% - Insulin production stops & Counter regulatory hormone glucagon, Catecholamines, growth hormone → Neutralize blood sugar.
  • Whipple’s triad
  • Fasting hypoglycemia <54 mg/dl
  • Immediate relief of symptoms with IV glucose
  • Symptom of hypoglycemia

Clinical features

  • Eccentric psychiatric behavior due to neuroglecopenia
  • Emotional outburst: mis dx as personality disorder.
  • Classic hallmark of whipple's triad may be missed. It includes symptoms of hypoglycemia especially with fasting with low blood suger and reversal of symptoms with glucose administration.

questions.text: A 21 year-old girl, sexually active for the past 3 years. Her family history is negative for cancer and cardiac disease. Examination is unremarkable. Pap smear was done, shows normal findings. Repeat cytology should be done after the duration of ?

  • Time to do PAP smear
    • Any women >21 yrs of age.
    • Any women 3 yrs after 1st sexual exposure in India
    • From 21 to 29 yrs, sexually active women should have cytology every 3 yrs
    • From 30 to 65 yrs: CO- TEST(PAP+ HPV) : If negative then 5 yearly. If only cytology done, then once in 3 yrs if cytology is negative
    • In high risk females (who have recently been treated for cervical dysplasia or who are HIV positive ), should undergo Pap smear examination annually ; provided the previous few consecutive Pap smears are normal.
    • After 65 yrs : no more PAP, if 3 cytology are negative or 2 CO-TEST are negative.

questions.text: A 10 year old boy was playing with his friends and fell down from a tree injuring his head. Suspecting his ICP was raised, which is the most effective way of management in a case of Raised ICP?
questions.solution:

Goals: ICP = < 20 mmHg

CPP => 60 mmHg

(CPP = MAP-ICP = 95-20 = 75 mmHg)

MC type of brain herniation : Transtentorial Herniation.

  • IV Mannitol

IV 3% saline

  • IV acetazolamide
  • Pediatric raised ICT → IV furosemide
  • NG tube Glycerol

Note : 5% Dextrose Hypotonic fluid is Contraindicated in stroke patient because it will worsen the neurological status.

2. Ventriculostomy - Most Effective

  • ICP monitor catheter deployed into frontal horn of lateral ventricle, it will sense the pressure continuously when it rises above >25mm Hg, one way valve will open that is located at the tip of catheter.
  • CSF: Flows out into sterile container. It is a Fully Automated process.

3. Vasopressors : NE, Dopamine → to increase Mean arterial pressure (MAP) because increasing MAP can compensate for raised ICP therefore Cerebral perfusion pressure can be maintained.

4. E. Tube + IPPV = Respiratory Rate is kept on higher side that results in CO, washout. This leads to vasoconstriction of Choroid Plexus Capillaries &results in decreased CSF production

Normal CSF production 20ml / Hr

Total amount of CSF = 150 ml

  • This method is called as Elective Hyperventilation (Least effective as it has temporary effect)

questions.text: A 23 year old male came in due to fever, chest pain, cough, dyspnea for the past 1 week. He visited the hospital as he was not relieved by medications. Auscultation showed dullness in the middle and lower lobe of right lung. CXR showed pleural effusion. After pleural tap, the exudate was sent to the lab which revealed gross appearance of Turbid to purulent, RBC - 4000/mcL, WBC – 95000 P cells/mcL, Glucose less than serum levels. What might be the possible cause in this patient?
questions.solution:
Characterisitcs of important Exudative pleural effusion:

Etiology or type of Effusion Gross appearnce White Blood cell count (Cells/ mcL) Red Blood cell count (Cells/ mcL) Glucose Comments
Malignancy Turbid to bloody: occasionally serous 1000 to < 100,000 M 100 to several hundred thousand Equal to serum level: < 60 mg / dl. In 15% of cases. Eosinophilia uncommon; positive result on cytologic examination
Uncomplicated parapneuimonic Clear to turbid 5000 - 25,000 p < 5000 Equal to serum levels Tube thoracotomy unnecessary
Emphysema Turbid to purulent 25,000 - 100,000 P < 10,000 Equal to serum levels: occasionally < 60 mg/dL. Protein > 4.0 g/dL); eosinophils cells (> 10%) or mesothelial cells (>5%) make diagnosis unlikely : see text for additional diagnostic tests
Rheumatoid Turbid: greenish yellow 1000 - 20,000 M or P < 1,000 < 40 mg/dL Secondary emphysema common; high LD, low complement, high rheumatoid factor, cholesterol crystal are characteristic

questions.text: Most stable wave of BERA is:
questions.solution:
Largest wave ,Most Stable and Most significant wave in BERA is Wave V

SITE OF ORIGIN OF WAVES

Wave I - Distal part of Eighth nerve

questions.text: A 32 year old Male presented with Chest pain recently. Further history confirmed that he had been having low grade fever at night for the past few weeks and night sweats and involuntary weight loss over 6 months. On ausculation, you find Pericardial friction rub. ECG findings show concave ST elevation, T wave inversion. You confirm the diagnosis as TB pericarditis and start ATT for 6 months. What’s the complication of a treated case of TB pericarditis?
questions.solution:
Tubercular Pericarditis

M/C extrapulmonary TB = Cervical Lymph Node

Gohn's focus = Tonsils

Clinical features:

  1. Chest pain at rest
  2. Night Sweats
  3. Low grade fever (Evening rise of temp.)
  4. Involuntary weight loss = Decrease in 5% weight over 6 months

On Examination:

Auscultatory findings- Pericardial friction Rub (Inflammation btw the outermost layers of heart and there is sero - fibrinous exudate present)

It persists on holding breath

  • Pleural Rub is heard best on deep Inspiration
  • Breath holding is the best method to differentiate btw these two Investigation:

Investigation:

1. ECG Findings:

  • ST segment elevation Concave upwards In contrast,In Myocardial infarction ST Elevation is convex upwards [Pardee Sign / Tombstone pattern]
  • It is also associated with T wave inversion ho
  • In acute pericarditis ~11 out of 12 leads are having ST elevation except in aVR, which shows reciprocal change of ST depression.
  • In a normal person P wave and I wave are always upside down so we will get a reciprocal change of ST segment depression.

2. Echocardiography: minimal pericardial effusion may be seen

3. CB NAAT/gene Xpert: On pericardial fluid

Treatment

Antitubercular treatment (ATT) x 6 months

Complications/Sequalae:

Constrictive pericarditis

Sequalae of treated case of tubercular pericarditis

Calcification like eggshell develop around the heart of a person which will limit the filling of heart from outside

Turbulence is created in diastole when the blood strikes the calcified ventricle

Auscultatory finding = Pericardial shudder/Pericardial shock/Pericardial knock

Pericardial shudder is always heard after opening snap

  • Pericardial Shudder mimics 3rd Heart sound
  • Pericardial Shudder=High pitch Heart Sound (Heard with diaphragm of stethoscope)

Note: Mid systolic clicks are heard in Mitral Valve Prolapse (MVP)

questions.text: A 21 year old male came in due to complaint of low back pain for the past 6 months. He claims that the pain usually subsides after taking analgesics, but recently there is no improvement. He says that the pain is more after waking up in the morning which bothers him so much that he couldn’t go for work. On examination, tenderness was noted at sacroiliac joint and buttock atrophy was noted with limitation in lateral bending. Further tests revealed HLA B27 +, X ray spine is given below, what is the most common cause of death in this condition?
questions.solution:
Spondyloarthropathy (SPA): spine ache is the mnemonic

Lateral bending: decreased

Mnemonic for features of SPA:SPINE-ACHE

  • Sausage digits
  • Psoriasis

Inflammatory back pain

NSAIDS responsive

  • Enthesopathy
  • Arthritis

Crohn/UC

  • HLA B27+
  • Eye: uveitis (MC extra- articular manifestation of ankylosing spondylitis)
  • > MC cause of death in AS: fracture of rigid osteoporotic spine > A.R>CAD
  • MC valve involvement in spondylitis patient - Aortic valve (aortic regurgitation)

These patient also have lHD and 3rddegree heart block.

  • Upper lobe fibrosis are seen in this patient.
  • Spinal cord involvement manifest as Cauda equina syndrome.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency room after a road traffic accident, the patient had facial trauma and a dislocation a DIP of 2nd toe was noted. FAST was negative for blood collection. GCS – 7. B.P – 90/60 mm Hg. Airway was cleared right away and intubation was done. What might be causing exsanguination leading to shock in this case?

choices.text: External blood loss on the floor at the site of accident

questions.solution:
5 major locations that cause Exsanguination leading to Shock

  1. External blood loss (on the floor at the site of accident)
  2. Chest
  3. Abdomen
  4. Retroperitoneum (pelvic fracture)
  5. Multiple long bone fracture

During initial physical examination

Identify source of external bleeding - Direct pressure over the site of bleeding

  • Identify Long bone fracture -Splinting should be done

Investigations done

  • CXR- to evaluate Thoracic blood loss
  • X-Ray Pelvis – to identify Pelvic fracture
  • FAST-for evaluation of Abdomen
  • CECT is not done in 1° survey
  • Two most important X-ray in trauma patient CXR (PA)
  • Xray pelvis (AP view)
  • In non-responding pts. With ongoing signs of shock Manage ongoing bleeding Blood transfusion

questions.text: A 23 year old P1L1 woman presents to the clinic for advice regarding natural methods of contraception and safe days for intercourse. The doctor explains about cervical mucous method and examines her cervical mucous under a microscope after smearing it on a slide. The mucous shows a pattern that is suggestive for high estrogen state. Which of the following mucus findings is associated with estrogen?
questions.solution:
• The Ferning of the cervical mucus is because of the high estrogen content and its DOES NOT diagnose ovulation.
  • Maximum before ovulation and once ovulation happens, the ferning actually reduces and finally disappears due to the high progesterone. This implies that loss of ferning pattern is suggestive of ovulation.
  • Maximum before ovulation and once ovulation happens, the ferning actually reduces and finally disappears due to the high progesterone. This implies that loss of ferning pattern is suggestive of ovulation.

questions.text: A primigravida gets a routine ultrasound with antenatal doppler done at 30 weeks. Her fetal parameters correspond to 30 weeks and umbilical artery S/D ratio is 2.8. She is advised to continue with her prenatal supplements and daily fetal movement counts. She returns after 4 weeks and the ultrasound is repeated. She has no high risk factor and is perceiving fetal movements well, what is the S/D ratio in umbilical artery expected at this visit?

choices.text: Constant at 2.8 with a diastolic notch

questions.solution:
• The systolic/diastolic (S/D) ratio of flow velocities was measured as an index of peripheral resistance.
  • The S/D ratio normally declines from appx. 4 at 20 weeks gestation, to generally <3 after 30 weeks and finally to 2 at birth
  • Doppler indices show a continuous reduction throughout the second half of pregnancy without any plateau or increase near term.

questions.text: Surgeries done in which zone of the hand causes poor results?
questions.solution:
Flexor tendons are derived into 5 zones base on their level.

Zone I → FDP

Zone II → FDS- called “No man’s land” (as surgeries done in Zone II causes poor result)

Zone III → Lumbricals

Zone IV → carpel tunnel

Zone V → Forearm

questions.text: What is the type of hair loss depicted in this image?
questions.solution:
Androgenic alopecia - hair loss due to androgens and underlying genetic predisposition.

Patterned hair loss is of two types:

a) Male pattern. In which there is Hamilton pattern of hair loss. It involves frontal hairline recedes backwards · This recession is more prominent in temporal area · hair loss from vertex · Miniature hair seen due to reduced anagen phase · vellus hair increases & Terminal hair decreases in sites invlolved.

b) Female pattern has Ludwig pattern hair loss in which frontal hair line maintained but hair loss from frontal &vertex portion · frontal hair line maintained but hair loss from partition site.

questions.text: A 29 year old drug addict and alcoholic was brought to emergency department for severe abdominal pain in the right upper quadrant. The patient also complained of body pain, pruritus and numbness in the extremities. On clincial examination, Palmar erythema, pedal edema and clubbing were noted. What is the investigation of choice in this patient?
questions.solution:
HEPATITIS C

  • Single stranded RNA virus
  • Leading cause of End stage liver disease (ESLD]

  • • Most common cause of Transmission is Parenteral IV drug abusers (IVDA)> B.T (Blood transfusion)

C/F:

Extrahepatic manifestations like Athralgia, Myalgia, Parasthesias, Pruritus &sicca syndrome like manifestations

Workup

1. E.I.A (enzyme immunoassay)anti HCV antibody e; can be false positive in patients with autoimmune hepatatis

2. IOC: PCR HCV RNA

3. LFT: SGPT may be normal/increased

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is refeeding syndrome not seen?
questions.solution:
Refeeding syndrome has been described in high-risk populations, including patients with eating disorders, depression, renal failure, malabsorptive conditions, previous bariatric surgery, and alcohol abuse. One of the main guidelines used for the evaluation and treatment of refeeding syndrome is the National Institute for Health Care and Excellence (NICE) guideline, which defines risk factors for refeeding syndrome as a “low body mass index (BMI), unintentional weight loss, starvation, history of alcohol abuse, and low initial electrolyte concentrations.”

Important lab abnormalities of Refeeding syndrome are:

  • Hypophosphatemia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Hypokalaemia
  • Glucose intolerance
  • Thiamine deficiency

INTRAVAGINAL TESTICULAR TORSION

Spiral attachment of Cremasteric fibers over the cord Brisk cremasteric reflex - Testicular torsion

Predisposing factor

  • MC-Inversion of Testes
  • Bell clapper's deformity

Separation of testis from body of epididymis

Blue Dot sign: Torsion of appendage of testis

Clinical features

  • Severe agonizing pain
  • Nausea & Vomiting

On examination affected testis-> High Riding in upper part of scrotum - Deming Sign Contralateral testis is normally lying, placed transversely Due to mesorchium-> Angel Sign - PREHNS SIGN --ve

  • Cremastericreflex - Absent

Treatment-Emergency Orchidopexy within 4 Hours

Diagnosis

  • USG - Anatomy

Doppler - for flow

  • Combined - Duplex scan

IOC-Doppler

Anywhere flow needs to be assessed: Doppler is lOC like Portal Hypertension

  • DVT
  • W
  • TT Varicocele

Duplex – 10CW, DVT

  • Tc Pertechnate scan-> decrease uptake of radionuclide

Treatment-Orchidopexy

  • Contralateral hemiscrotum should be explored.

Bilateral Orchidopexy- Performed.

  • In case of ischemic testis->Orchidectomy + Prosthesis

questions.text: A 38-year-old female presents to the clinic regarding contraception counseling for using the vaginal diaphragm. The gynecology professor explains to her various methods of contraception. She also sequentially explains the causes of the failure of contraception. Then she demonstrated the insertion technique and taught about the use of barrier contraceptives to her. According to the expert gynecologist’s opinion, when should the vaginal diaphragm be removed?
questions.solution:
Option B: After 6-8 hours

 

  • After intercourse, the vaginal diaphragm and vault cap should not be removed before 6–8 h of the last act and should not be kept for more than 24 h.
  • Best time to introduce it is from a few minutes to 2 h before the sexual act,
  • Spermicides must be used along with these devices.
  • Contraindications:
    • Prolapse, cystocele, rectocele because the accurate fitting is not possible.
    • Recurrent urinary tract infection.
    • Allergy to rubber or spermicidal agent.
  • Toxic shock syndrome (TSS) may occur if the diaphragm is left in the vagina for a long period
  • After intercourse, the vaginal diaphragm and vault cap should not be removed before 6–8 h of the last act and should not be kept for more than 24 h.

Incorrect Option A : Immediately

  • Removing diaphragm immediately or after 1 hour can cause some sperms to still ascend and cause a pregnancy.

Incorrect Option C : After 24 hours

  • Removal after 24 hours can lead to severe reactions or even toxic shock syndrome.

Incorrect Option D : After 1 hour

  • Removing diaphragm immediately or after 1 hour can cause some sperms to still ascend and cause a pregnancy.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not correct about the image given below?

choices.text: It’s the Miller laryngoscope. It is the most common type of curved laryngoscope blade
It is used for pediatric intubation
The most common complication of this procedure is a sore throat,
MC position for this procedure is the Reverse Trendelenberg

questions.solution:
This is miller laryngoscope used for pediatric intubation to lift up the whole epiglottis .

The straight Miller laryngoscope blade is traditionally recommended for intubation in infants, due to the large size and flexibility of the infant epiglottis.

A laryngoscope is an instrument used to examine the larynx. The classic laryngoscope is available with a variety of blade attachments and with/without a Fiber Optic light source. The trend regarding blades has/is moving toward the disposable version.

Function:

Laryngoscope blades are used as the primary tool for examination of the interior of the larynx and for placement of an endotracheal tube.

Main Features:

The Miller Laryngoscope Blade

The most popular of the straight types. The tongue is straight with a slight curve near the tip.

In cross section, the flange, web and tongue form a 'C' with the top flattened. Some versions of the blade have lamp socket on the tongue others have it on the web.

The lamp may be on the right or left side, the bulb is easier to change but can be covered by the tongue if the bulb is on the left side. If placed on the right side, it is protected by the flange.

The force, head extension and cervical spine movement are all less compared to Macintosh blade during intubation The side of the flange is reduced to minimize trauma and the curve at the beak or tip is extended to improve lifting of the epiglottis. These improvements facilitate greater exposure of the larynx in difficult-to-intubate patients.

questions.text: A 25 years old female came to ENT OPD with complaints of B/L hearing loss and also complaints of better hearing whenever she is in the market with her husband. On further examination a flamingo pink color of tympanic membrane is seen. W hat is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Otosclerosis also known as otospongiosis predominant in females (20-30 years) autosomal dominant pattern B/L CHL

Schwartz sign- flamingo pink color of tympanic membrane

pure tone audiometry-carhart's notch- dip at 2000 Hz in bone conduction

PARACUSISWILLISII:Patient hears better in noisy than in quiet surroundings.

  • Exact etiology of otosclerosis is not known.
  • In otosclerosis family history/heredity plays an important role.
  • About 50% of patients of otosclerosis have a positive family history.
  • It is an automosal dominant condition

Shows incomplete penetranceand variable expression

questions.text: Most common cause of occipito-posterior presentation:
questions.solution:
Etiology of occipito post presentation is-

  1. Mostly idiopathic
  2. Most common cause of op position → anthropoid and android pelvis
  3. Android pelvis causes deep transverse arrest and anthropoid pelvis causes face to pubis
  4. It is M/C in nulliparous females
  5. Marked deflection of fetal head, also favor posterior position of the vertex
  6. Presentation more common seen in association with anterior placentation
  7. If no rotation toward the symphysis takes place, the occiput may remain in the direct occiput posterior presentation, a condition known as persistent occiput posterior.

questions.text: An 8 weeks pregnant woman presents for routine ultrasound. USG is suggestive of a live intrauterine pregnancy of 8 weeks with a 3 cm right ovarian simple cyst. Which of the following is the most appropriate management ?

choices.text: No treatment required, with follow up
Remove at time of cesarean section

questions.solution:
For ovarian cysts ≥10 cm, because of the substanial risk of malignancy, torsion, or labor obstruction, surgical removal is reasonable option.

Surgery is preferably done in the second trimester.

Management of simple ovarian cysts in pregnancy

  • < 5 cm : Usually remain asymptomatic and require no treatment. Only follow up to be done
  • 5 - 10 cm : follow up with ISG and doppler. Resection to be done in case of
    • suspicion of malignancy
    • sudden growth
    • becomes symptomatic
    • torsion
  • >10 cm : to be removed, preferably in the second trimester

questions.text: A 45 year old male presents with chest pain, dizziness, altered mental status and CHF features. On examination, HR is 55 bpm, BP 112/68 mm Hg. ECG shows increased R-R interval. You diagnose the case as Symptomatic bradycardia. What is the first Step of management?
questions.solution:
Management algorithm of symptomatic bradycardia

1. IV atropine 1mg every 3-5 min

  • Maximum dose = 3 mg
  • If Atropine fails then— TCP

2. IV epinephrine drip

  • Activates B1 in the heart
  • Dose 2-109 g/kg/minute

3. IV Dobutamine (2-20pg/Kg/min)

  • Activate B1, D1 receptors

4. Transcutaneous Pacing

5. Transvenous pacing

  • Remember first line is atropine but we will not wait to first give

6 dosage and then go to pacing. If no response to atropine and heart rate is low, start T.C.P.)

questions.text: This change was observed in the capnograph in patient under general anesthesia in midsurgery. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
In malignant hyperthermia → Metabolism becomes 2-3 times the normal → Et CO2 ↑↑↑ses.

Malignant hyperthermia is an autosomal dominantly inherited disorder characterized by skeletal muscle hypermetabolism following exposure to halogenated anesthetics, depolarizing muscle relaxants such as succinylcholine, or, occasionally, physiologic stressors. The gene for the ryanodine receptor RYR1 is the primary site for mutations linked with malignant hyperthermia.

questions.text: A newly born infant to a healthy mother with no history of illness has an abnormal cry at the time of his birth. He is having difficulty in breathing. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
• Laryngeal web is due to incomplete recanalization of larynx.
  • Mostly, the web is seen between vocal cords and has a concave posterior margin.
  • Presenting features are airway obstruction, weak cry or aphonia dating from birth.
  • Laryngomalacia is associated with normal cry at birth, Subglottic Hemangioma manifest few months after birth
